channel.title: Divertimenti
channel.description: This is a collection of opinions, thoughts, projects, and things I have enjoyed reading and studying.

item.title: Who is up for a game of ... however this thing is called?
item.description: You will think that in the age of AI-powered search, identifying a game like this provided a description or a picture would be a matter of seconds. Not quite.

item.title: Turtles all the way down, understanding the foundations
item.description: The History of Philosophy Without Any Gaps is an impressive project that began in 2010 with the ambitious goal of covering the entire history of philosophy in a concise yet comprehensive and nearly systematic way.

item.title: Who is up for a programming challenge?
item.description: Is anyone still doing good, old-fashioned machine learning or programming? Or is everyone prompting and trying to tame LLMs (and asking themselves why)? Here's a small programming challenge â€”an old-fashioned brain teaser and a balm for the soul.

item.title: A programming language for describing (most) of the world
item.description: A MIT/GNU Scheme kernel for Jupyter. Scheme is a functional programming language that is well-suited for describing symbolic mathematics and classical mechanics, among other things.

item.title: A physics- and geometry-aware programming language for telling love stories
item.description: Discover how Stellarium's scripting engine can be used to create engaging astronomical stories and educational content for children.

item.title: Repetition is the mother of learning
item.description: On the powerful and pervasive ideas in Shannon seminal paper.

item.title: The Martian
item.description: A fascinating fictionalized account of John von Neumann's life and his pivotal role in the history of computing. One book by von Neumann and two by Benjamin Labatut.

item.title: Principles vs. Facts
item.description: Graph representations provide the basic principles necessary to understand and generalize to the most relevant architectures, including CNNs, transformers, and, of course, GNNs.

item.title: Don't mess up with zeros and infinities
item.description: A Numberphile video that didn't go very well.

item.title: Programming by the Ten Commandments
item.description: On how LLMs are coming full circle to resemble programming, but with a few caveats.

item.title: What ants can teach us about optimization
item.description: Have you seen the Scooby-Doo meme claiming that machine learning is really statistics? Well, guess what? Machine learning is actually optimization (if you dig a little deeper, you'll find that everything is actually optimization ðŸ˜œ).

item.title: Philosophy is not dead
item.description: A book by Adam Becker about the fascinating history and disputes surrounding the interpretations of quantum mechanics.

item.title: Look up (part II)
item.description: Constellations are celestial landmarks and a source of awe and inspiration for myths. They are also a canvas on which humans have painted their mythologies. This is a Stellarium remote control for kids.

item.title: Look up!
item.description: We often use the word "navigate" in a figurative sense. We want children to learn this or that in order to navigate the world better. What about learning (and teaching) to actually navigate the world?

item.title: On the importance of unread books
item.description: This is a beautiful, short book by Hermann Weyl on a topic at the core of nature, conservation laws, and physics in general.

item.title: The Arabian nights of numbers
item.description: The most poetic math book a young person can read.

item.title: The Three Body Problem
item.description: An amazing book on one of my favorite topics ever, calculus of variations.

item.title: Game theory ðŸ˜‰
item.description: A book on the history of games and how deeply human, and intertwined with our culture and essence games are.

item.title: Fantastic numbers and where fo find them
item.description: Does energy weigh? And if energy weighs, and given how information is stored, does information weigh? If information really weighs, can my head collapse into a black hole when I think of or memorize the decimal representation of a very large number?

item.title: The Napkin Project
item.description: A massive, beautifully excuted and formatted math project. An Infinitely Large Napkin.

item.title: Mindstorms, how kids learn and create
item.description: On how I thought myself to juggle by reading a book by Seymour Papert.

item.title: Alice in Differentiable Wonderland
item.description: Down the rabbit hole of differentiable programming and modern DL architectures, a book by Simone Scardapane.

item.title: A romance on higher dimensions
item.description: This tiny book by Edwin A. Abbot is a masterpiece of mathematical and geometrical adventure; it is also a social satire and a romance. What more can you ask for in a book?

item.title: My favourite book on machine learning
item.description: This book is simply superb, a model of how to teach and present ideas. If I ever write a technical book, this is how I would like to do it.

item.title: A fool's approach to learning quantum computing
item.description: My personal journey of trying to learn quantum computing.

item.title: A presentation on mathematical optimization
item.description: General introduction to mathematical optimization, algebraic modeling languages, and the Julia programming language for optimization.

item.title: El patio
item.description: I am more of a reader than a writer, but as they say, "If you never try...". A short story in Spanish.

item.description: Why did I choose the most improbably Polish name as my nome de plume? ðŸ˜†
